## Get Ready

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
Beijing_Data <- read.csv("PRSA_data_2010.1.1-2014.12.31.csv", header = T)
# No: row number 
# year: year of data in this row 
# month: month of data in this row 
# day: day of data in this row 
# hour: hour of data in this row 
# pm2.5: PM2.5 concentration (ug/m^3) 
# DEWP: Dew Point (â„ƒ) 
# TEMP: Temperature (â„ƒ) 
# PRES: Pressure (hPa) 
# cbwd: Combined wind direction 
# Iws: Cumulated wind speed (m/s) 
# Is: Cumulated hours of snow 
# Ir: Cumulated hours of rain 
library(dplyr)
library(zoo)
library(lars)
library(ridge)
library(car)
library(MASS)
library(Hmisc)

```

## Data Summary 

```{r}
head(Beijing_Data)
tail(Beijing_Data)
cbwd <- Beijing_Data$cbwd
Beijing_Data <- Beijing_Data[,-c(1,5,10)]

```

There are $12$ variables in this data set: 
| Variable Name | Variable Explanation  |
| :-----------: | :-------------------: |
| No | row number |
| Year | year of data in this row |
| Month | month of data in this row |
| Day | day of data in this row |
| Hour | hour of data in this row |
| PM 2.5 | PM 2.5 concentration (ug/m^3) |
| DEWP | Dew Point |
| TEMP | Temperature |
| PRES | Pressure |
| cbwd | Combined wind direction | 
| lws | Cumulated wind speed | 
| ls | Cumulated hours of snow |
| lr | Cumulated hours of rain |

We want to find out a model to analyze this data set and predict the fulture data. 

## Data Preprocessing 

### Handling Missing Values 

First, we have to check if there are missing values,

```{r}
length(Beijing_Data[is.na(Beijing_Data) == T])
```

There are $2067$ missing values out of all $434824$ obervations of PM2.5 values (nearly 4.7%), which we can not omit. We can use interpolated values to approch to those NA by using `R` function: `na.approx` which is using the linear interpolation. After the approximation, we can found that there are still 24 missing value in the column: PM2.5. Since there are the head of this column, there is no initial value for the linear interpolation, that's why we used the closest value (the $25th$ data) to approximate the $1st$ to the $24th$ data

```{r}
head(Beijing_Data, 25)
Beijing_Data$pm2.5 <- na.approx(Beijing_Data$pm2.5, na.rm = F, rule = 2)
Beijing_Data$pm2.5[1:24] <- Beijing_Data$pm2.5[25]
head(Beijing_Data, 26)
tail(Beijing_Data)
```

Since this data set is a time series related data set, and in this data set, the it has collected the pm2.5 for every hour. To reduce the the correlation between time and the pm2.5 data, we use the average of values of one day's data. Our model is linear regression. We assume that 

Categorical Variable $\Rightarrow$ CBWD 
```{r}
cbwd <- as.numeric(cbwd)
```

```{r}
norm.Beijing.data <- scale(new.Beijing.data)
norm.Beijing.data <- as.data.frame(norm.Beijing.data)
new.Beijing.data$day <- seq(1, 1826, by = 1)
```

Data visualize

```{r}
i <- NULL
for(i in 4:10){
  hist(new.Beijing.data[,i],freq = F, col = "blue")
}
names(new.Beijing.data[,4:10])
```

```{r}
lm1 <- lm(pm2.5~., data = new.Beijing.data) # full model
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
plot(lm1)
summary(lm1)
```

Since the Q-Q plot's line has a curling up 's tail, so we can note that the distribution is right skew. We can do the numerical transformation 

```{r}
lm2 <- lm(log(pm2.5)~year + month + day + DEWP + TEMP + PRES + Iws + Is + Ir, data = new.Beijing.data) # take the natural logarithm to PM2.5 data
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
plot(lm2)
```

## Model Diagnostics

To chack if the model is useful, we have to verify and diagnose it:
1. independent variables and dependent variable have a linear correlation;
2. the residuasl are following the normal distribution;
3. the residuals' variance are the same. (homoscedasticity);
4. residuals are i.i.d..

```{r}
lm.step <- step(lm2) # AIC selection 
par(mfrow= c(2,2))
plot(lm.step)
```
```{r}
lm.norm <- lm(log(pm2.5)~., data = norm.Beijing.data)
summary(lm.norm)
par(mfrow=c(2,2))
plot(lm.norm)
```
